Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Geographic Extent of Late Pleistocene Subsurface Ocean Warming in the Northern Atlantic Ocean Basin and the Origin of Heinrich Events

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will examine the triggering mechanisms of Heinrich events, which are a widely recognized expression of abrupt global climate change. Heinrich events are interpreted as massive discharges of icebergs calved from the Laurentide Ice Sheet, the ice mass that covered a large share of the North American continent during the last ice age. The climatic context of Heinrich events was global in scale. Identifying these events therefore is an integral part of millennial-scale global climate change. The physical processes that triggered these events remain poorly understood, however. This doctoral dissertation research project will develop high-resolution records of North Atlantic Ocean subsurface water temperature bracketing known Heinrich events using magnesium-to-calcium ratios in seafloor-dwelling organisms in order to evaluate an external triggering mechanism for Heinrich events attributed to changes in oceanic circulation. This approach will employ a new analytical method for Mg-Ca paleothermometry on seafloor-dwelling organisms. Analysis of one ocean sediment core raised from the outer Labrador Sea basin suggested that bottom-water temperatures warmed before stratigraphic signatures of Heinrich events at that core location. Replication and further assessment of the geographic distribution of this pattern is necessary in order to establish its role as a forcing mechanism of Heinrich events. Exploratory data from the Reykjanes Ridge and the Labrador Sea have shown that the ocean sediment cores targeted for this project at the depths and locations of interest contain Heinrich event signatures and material necessary in order to carry out this project's research goals.

The study of abrupt ice sheet destabilization and oceanic change has significant implications for future climate. Confirmation that intermediate-depth ocean warming played a significant role in triggering past ice-sheet instabilities will provide critical insights into potential future behavior of similarly configured Antarctic ice-sheet sectors. The project could provide validation for ice-sheet models currently being developed for projections of land-ice loss and attendant sea level rise. The project also will yield new data to test the accuracy of a new accessory developed by the doctoral student for use with plasma mass spectrometers in order to more effectively measure Mg-Ca paleothermometry in marine sediments. The project should improve understanding of the response of ice sheets to current and possible future changes in ocean circulation and temperature, factors which are among the greatest causes for concern and uncertainty in projections of sea-level rise. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Few discoveries have galvanized the interest of the paleoclimate community more than the so-called Heinrich events, or episodic destabilizations of the marine-terminating sectors of the Laurentide Ice Sheet and other circum-Atlantic ice sheets during the last glacial cycle. However, the underlying mechanism that initiated the ice-sheet instability that caused Heinrich events is still debated. This research evaluated the hypothesis that Heinrich events were triggered by subsurface warming following a strong reduction in the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation (AMOC). Geochemical measurements on benthic foraminifera from several intermediate-depth sites in the North Atlantic established the timing and amplitude of warming relative to Heinrich events, with particular emphasis on Heinrich event 1. This research provides a critical test of the hypothesis that subsurface warming was responsible for triggering Heinrich events. The results of this study helped resolve the otherwise enigmatic climatic context of Heinrich events. These results also provide a dramatic demonstration of a possible future scenario of land-ice response to changing ocean circulation and temperature.

Broader Impacts

This research is a multidisciplinary effort that combined the expertise of paleoceanographers and geologists to address a widely discussed aspect of abrupt climate change associated with past interactions of ice sheets and ocean circulation. This work thus has direct societal relevance by having developed an improved understanding of the response of ice sheets to current and possible future changes in ocean circulation and temperature, which are among the greatest causes for concern in projections of land-ice loss and consequent sea-level rise. In particular, confirming that subsurface warming played a significant role in triggering past ice-sheet instabilities provides important insights into possible future behavior of similarly configured Antarctic and Greenland ice-sheet sectors if warmer waters penetrate beneath their large, buttressing ice shelves or to their grounding lines. It also provides evidence that can be used as a critical validation experiment for future ice-sheet model experiments that are being developed for making projections of future land-ice loss. The proposal trained a Ph.D. student in modern methods of paleoceanography while exposing the student to highly interdisciplinary research. This proposal also supported an undergraduate student in all phases of laboratory and analytical work and data interpretation, with the final product being an Honor’s Thesis.

Outcomes

Based on trace metal (Mg/Ca) and stable isotope (δ18O and δ13C) measurements on benthic foraminifera, the results of this research suggest that most of the early deglacial benthic δ18O variability across the North Atlantic basin can be attributed to subsurface warming. These results are corroborated by comparison of a basin-wide network of intermediate depth benthic δ18O records to synthetic Δδ18O records estimated from transient deglacial climate model output. Empirical Orthogonal Function analysis reveals that this basin-wide subsurface warming signal paralleled an inferred reduction in the AMOC and led the arrival of Heinrich event icebergs to the North Atlantic basin. These results confirm the presence of a warm subsurface ocean during Heinrich Stadial 1 in response to a reduction in AMOC and further support the hypothesis that Heinrich events were caused by, not the cause of, changes in ocean circulation and glacial climate.
